Abstract: Photosystem II (PSII) is a crucial component of photosynthesis, responsible for the light-dependent reactions that drive the conversion of light energy into chemical energy. The evolution of PSII has been a pivotal event in the origin of life on Earth, with cyanobacteria emerging as the primary candidates for the earliest photosynthetic organisms. Through a comprehensive analysis of the structural and functional properties of PSII, this study explores the evolution and evolvability of this complex. The discovery of the D1 protein, a key component of PSII, has provided valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying photosynthesis. Our research reveals that the evolution of PSII has been shaped by a complex interplay of genetic and environmental factors, resulting in the diverse range of PSII variants found in modern cyanobacteria. The findings of this study have significant implications for our understanding of the origin of life and the evolution of photosynthesis, highlighting the critical role of PSII in the development of life on Earth.
